title: Monday, 11th February 2019
bodyHTML:
Nately Ahoy
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Monday already, huh. Seems like we were barely apart.

BE11:12am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever.

LegalEagle Morning
BE11:12am

And what on earth happened here?

VV75 morning
FATDAZ Morning all glorious sunshine in London
11:12 am
BE11:13am

https://markets.ft...9R2UU2JLVEGFDBI5UJ

BE11:13am

SPORTS DIRECT INTERNATIONAL PLC

("Sports Direct" or the "Company")

Offer for Patisserie Valerie

Sports Direct International plc ("the Company" or "the Group") confirms that it has made an offer to acquire the business comprising the trade and assets of Patisserie Holdings plc and its group companies out of administration.

Ends.

BE11:13am

"Ends".

Manxish Morning each
Flaneur So is the German govt going to take a ~33% share in DB, or what?And what EU rules need to be bent to aloow this?
Blank canvas good morning
red normal ashley play no?
Soundbuy Morning all
VV75 somebody told Mike he already had too much cake
Lemmy I briefly had visions of job lots of dough sitting on the shelves of Dickens&Jones
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Well, yes. It seems when you ... um, let's say bid, for want of a better word .... for a company a week after the auction rounds has closed having made no previous contact with the administrator, it does end pretty quick.

BE11:14am

Two days, in fact, though there's no RNS to that effect.

BE11:14am

https://www.ft.com...-ba00-0251022932c8

wayneJ Vertical integration by Sports Direct or a 'holistic offer' - encompassing products to enlarge you (Patisserie Valerie) and products / services to shrink you (Sports Direct gym). Perhaps every chocolate éclair will come with 10 mins gym membership?
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Sports Direct has pulled its offer to buy Patisserie Valerie after just two days, complaining of being shut out of the bidding process for the beleaguered café chain.

red @Flaneurdb will be paired off with a french bk, cmz bk doesnt move the needle. gov doesnt need to take a stake to be on tap if anything goes wrong, as already is.
Soundbuy Dunlop Doughnuts............can't wait...............
BE11:15am

On Sunday Sports Direct wrote to the Patisserie Valerie administrators, KPMG, complaining of lacking the information required to continue bidding for the group and its subsidiaries which include the Baker & Spice and Philpotts restaurant brands.

BE11:16am

Yes, it's outrageous. And Sports Direct refuses to sell me plimsolls when I turn up at 3am on a Sunday night.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

In the letter — which has been seen by the Financial Times — Mr Wootton said that “SD has not been allowed access to a data room, any financial information or meetings with management”.

BE11:17am

Bizarre. But not out of character I guess.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 270.70, up 0.3 (+0.11%), High: 271.30, Low: 266.30, Volume: 49.07k
11:17 am
undefined
Curious one does wonder how he envisions the synergies across his empire
A. M. Éclairs to be made in some warehouse
BE11:18am

@Flaneur, Re Deutsche Bank ... god knows.

Waterloo He's a bit like someone I know who just keeps buying print magazines.
Electric Dragon Ashley's grab bag of High St names - anyone reminded of Facia? That ended badly.
BE11:19am

The latest noise here seems to be via a WirtschaftsWoche story

11:19 am
BE11:19am

https://www.wiwo.d...EP6tbuNz7NYsba-ap3

Pharma @red, for added entertainment, DB could merge with Unicredit.
BE11:20am

And Reuters has a government source speaking off the record to say it's speculation.

wayneJ Administrators do have some flexibility. It does seem that SPD indicative offer was £15m+ --- one has to assume the administrator has had offers significantly above this or has strong belief that in a wind-down the amount achieved will be significantly above this level in order to proceed this way.
Flaneur @red/ @BE - silly internet stuff I know, its just someone pointed out that a botched Brexit deal would be a great cover/ scapegoat for a DB collapse and emergency state aid... to the tune of 33%...
wayneJ Also one would have thought that if the approach lasted 2 days - if that included a weekend - then a bit odd for SPD to pull out until at least allowing one working day ie Monday.
BE11:22am

But .... It's Monday. I can't face reading the German press, which is extraordinary for all the wrong reasons.

Montesquieu @Flaneur - we may be seeing the next stage of capitulation from European investment banks. The recent data regarding concentration of product market share and fee volumes makes particularly grim reading for DB and its European peers.
red unicredit not such a dog these days, the irony of it
11:21 am
undefined
nichoman wonder if DBs travails are an incentive for German government to reopen negotiations on brexit. presume they don't want to own it and am guessing plunging uk property values wouldn't be good for DB!
FATDAZ @BE et al Re Deutsche bank merging with commerz wont solve any of the issues that dog both banks it will just concentrate them -Retail banking in Germany is a not for profit biz and Investment banking on a global scale is capital intensive and high cost
BE11:22am

As to the UK, there's Smith & Nephew ......

BE11:23am

... Arash et al shook out the news on Friday that they're looking at Nuvasive.

11:23 am
Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,460, down 55.5 (-3.66%), High: 1,490, Low: 1,451, Volume: 892.62k
BE11:24am

Spine specialist. Price tag of $3bn-plus.

PBateman Morning everyone
BE11:24am

Report stresses it's early stage.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Generally, the sellside says "interesting target, very expensive".

BE11:25am

Here's Exane.

BE11:25am

As the global number three, NuVasive has consistently outgrown the Spine market thanks to its focus on innovation and agility as a pure player. More recently, NuVasive has generated strong growth ex-US (17% of FY17 revenues), offsetting the US weakness. However, after several years of double-digit growth, NuVasive’s has organic growth has slowed, to 7% in 2017 and 5% in 2018 We also note the company has recently been embroiled in legal issues (a case of sales poaching with distributor Madsen; litigation with a former Board member), while its track-record on guidance is mixed, with two cuts to the FY18 guidance. As such the shares have shed approx 30% in the past six months, now trading on c.23x P/E 19e (vs 19.5x pour S&N and 22x for Stryker).

PBateman Any grey on the nation's favourite turnaround specialists? (Melrose)
FATDAZ @red Unicredit sold bonds to Pimco ( billion of dollars worth ) at a coupon above their ROE that didn't strike me as as deal done by a player with a strong had
11:25 am
BE11:26am

Here's a surprising thing: spine stuff isn't growing much.

Pharma @BE I'm sad to see the demise of the full-stop in "et al." to denote the abbreviation.Must dash. Just off to pedants anonymous
BE11:26am

You'd have thought the office chair and the online warehouse would combine to make for a decent market.

BE11:27am

But no, ten-year average growth of just 1.5%

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Largely, it seems, because US private insurers won't pay to have your lumbar treatment.

FATDAZ strong hand
BE11:27am

Back to price.

BE11:27am

During the recent FY18 earnings call, S&N’s incoming CEO, Mr Nawana, insisted that
“adjacencies” represent a key focus for M&A, noting that this avoids the typical sales dis-synergies
observed with horizontal mergers in the industry. Moreover, before his tenure at Alere (2013–17),
Mr Nawana oversaw the integration of Spine specialist Synthes after its acquisition by J&J in 2012.
Assuming a 25% premium to NuVasive’s current share price, the cash-financed USD3.7bn deal
(incl. NuVasive net debt) would propel S&N’s ND/EBITDA to 2.6x at end-19e, implying 13.5x
EV/EBITDA, in line with the average for deals in the space (c. 14x EV/EBITDA).

FATDAZ @Pharma ouch you got me
11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@Pharma: your absolutely right to highlight it, I too cant stand bad grammar and punctuation).

BE11:29am

And Cantor, who say, "nah".

Pharma @BE, and quite write too,
BE11:29am

We think a Smith & Nephew acquisition of NUVA is unlikely because we think there are more attractive acquisition targets that would better-align with the goals of SNN's renewed M&A focus. Specifically, we think there are better potential acquisition targets in end markets adjacent to SNN with faster growth that would better-leverage SNN's existing businesses. NUVA's revenue growth in 2018 (~5%) was slightly faster than SNN's growth (~3%), but the overall spine market is growing by only 0-2%, below the market growth of SNN's current end markets (~4%). Additionally, NUVA's gross and operating margins would be dilutive to SNN. NUVA is also an organization in transition as it has switched CEOs, lowered operating margin expectations (3Q call) and pre-announced a 4Q revenue miss. We think it is possible that SNN has looked at NUVA as we believe NUVA was looking for acquisition suitors last year. It is possible that SNN might be compelled to add a spine business because it is the only large orthopedic company — others being ZBH (OW), JNJ (NC) and SYK (N) — that does not have a spine business. That said, we don’t think that would be reason for SNN to make the acquisition.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And ......... Baird?

BE11:30am

Our sense is there could be some legitimacy to these talks given:
- New SNN CEO Namal Nawana just last week noted a willingness to consider
bigger potential transactions in "adjacent markets."
- Mr. Nawana spent many years as President of JNJ's DePuy spine division,
while former NUVA EVP/Global Commercial Skip Kiil recently joined SNN as
President of the company's orthopedics division, meaning both senior executives
are extremely familiar with both NUVA and the broader spine market.
- We believe there could also be an argument for product development and
geographic synergies between the two companies over time, as we could
imagine an integrated system that someday includes technology from SNN's
NAVIO robot and NUVA's LessRay and Pulse systems, while SNN's long history
in China (since 1984, over 500 employees currently in roughly 50 Chinese cities)
could also help open a new market NUVA has long considered.

BE11:31am

That said, we also remind investors the Financial Times has highlighted a number
of deal-related discussions involving SNN in recent years that haven't panned
out, and we can't ignore the history of challenges we've seen with past spine
acquisitions.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

........uh, what? When?

BE11:31am

Where's all this fantasy M&A we've been churning out on S&N? Can't remember much of it.

wayneJ Isn't the issue with German banking really the local banks that are often partially or completely owned by local govt. A bit like building socs in the UK upto the late 1980s. Though they did social good they impacted the profit pool.
red @FATDAZdb presently winning all race sin terms of borrowing rates.
BE11:32am

There was the Stryker bid, which got a pens-down denial from Stryker -- but that led to Ed Hammond going after them like an attack dog and getting them to admit it.

red db's prob is balance sheet and cost base.
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Baird reckons chance of an offer is "~50/50 at best."

Viking1 How about Danske and DB?
undefined
A. M. (at the risk of antagonizing BE, I was much amused by a comment to the week end's vinyl revival story, where a millennial said they 'enjoy writing with real pens')
FATDAZ @red I cant be bullish about European banks as whole I am afraid and think the cracks will increasingly show now that QE has been withdrawn
Claret 50/50 and stock off nearly 5% crazy
red @FATDAZvalue trap
Flaneur @Fatdaz - actually, heard QE about to be revved up again in EU... what a mess they've made of the economies since 2008.No wonder theres political and social ** hitting the fan everywhere.
BE11:35am

Okay, sorry, offscreen for a moment .....

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Danske-DB?!?!?!?

FATDAZ @red I see it as unreconstructed sector that hasn't come to terms with commoditised earnings and margins which has now lost an important source of income and funding / cash flow
red @Flaneurwhere did u hear this? while its prob necessary, not sure there is enough political capital to do it.
Flaneur (@BE - yeah, chuck in Anglo-Irish and RBS and youve got a full house...)

As in a merger? Brilliant idea. A one-stop-shop for .... um, let's not develop on that point.

FATDAZ @flanneur can't rule that out but what climbdown that would be
BE11:37am

Since we're on banks though, there's some UK stuff worth sharing.

red under the guise of a nodeal brexit maybe, but still u feel its a hard sell. would only add to populism, which is already delicately poised.
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Morgan Stanley talking about the mortgage market continuing to stink.

BE11:38am

They're pro Lloyds, anti RBS

red for now they seem to be talking up the slowdown, to bring the euro lower, but talking down any recession in order to not add fuel to fire
FATDAZ @flanneur I see RBS is to pay a bonus and has £335 mln set aside for the task
Flaneur Priv conversation with trader/friend. Dont talk often but usually fairly tuned in. - says situation on Continent pretty grim and Brexit not helping.
BE11:38am

Mortgage front book pricing, slower growth and a flattening curve paint a difficult picture for UK NII in 2019. On 7-9x PE we see this as priced in and upgrade Lloyds, which we think will prove most resilient, to Overweight. We see most earnings risk at RBS and downgrade to Equal-weight.

Flaneur (Sorry last comment was in reply to @Red)
11:38 am
BE11:39am

We have seen mortgage rate reductions from incumbents such as Lloyds and Barclays as recently as January. Front book spreads on 2 and 5 year mortgages are now down to 60-75bp spread which we estimate will create a 4.5-6.5% NII headwind in UK this year and next alone. With pricing under pressure and economy slowing, banks with the highest growth are at risk of missing consensus NII expectations in our view.

BE11:39am

Says Lloyds is fine.

red if we could just get brexit out of the way, along with any markdown, lloyds is a good pick. until then the risk of markdown lingers
BE11:39am

We upgrade LLoyds to Overweight with a 78p PT. With a more seasoned book and greater than 20% market share, we see manageable pricing pressure for Lloyds, and we believe consensus c. 13-14% ROTE 2019/20E is realistic. Banks in Europe with similar profitability trade on 1.5x TBV vs. Lloyds at 1x. At a time when profitable business models are scarce in Europe, we believe the stock is too cheap to ignore despite macro risks, which we have factored in by doubling provisions. We include Lloyds in our European most preferred list, replacing Caixabank.

Pharma @red, is it Friday that Germany GDP figures come out? Question is whether they avoid a technical recession.
11:39 am
BE11:40am

RBS, not so much.

BE11:40am

Mortgage refinancing risk, higher loan growth expectations, and higher rate sensitivity puts RBS' NII more at risk in our view. We estimate stable NII vs. 2H18, and our overall revenues are 4% below consensus. At the same time, consensus and MS estimates are already expecting an 8-10% reduction in operating costs over the next two years, which limits offsets. We lower our operating profit 3-6% for RBS in this note, and move to Equal-weight. Share buyback potential should continue to offer valuation support, though may be pushed out.

Bluesky21 Lloyds in any case has been shrinking the mortgage part in their loan mix
undefined
Bluesky21 Unlike RBS and HSBC, still frantically trying to deploy that trapped cash from their now-ringfenced UK retail banks
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Okay, we're still talking Deutsche Bank on the right so guess we need to stick with it on the left.

Grouchmonkey Morning
red @Pharmano thats a wk on friday but plenty of uk data this wk.
FATDAZ @BE wouldn't this be Metro banks chance to shine as a challenger bank in mortgage market and offer something attractive to borrowers?

It's sensible to believe that a state bailout has been talked about, and also that no one would talk about such a thing publicly. No one wants to do a Peston.

Excel Developer @fatdaz: re an earlier remark about investment banks being capital intensive, is that why the only real IB players are US based. Given the deep pools of liquidity in dollar capital markets, unmatched by european or japanese capital markets.
Blackbag99 @1st I don't care.
Pharma @red, tradingeconomics site has flash Q4 release on the 14th

In terms of what would force the moment to a crisis .... dunno. Which is kind-of the point. But DB C-suite are out on tour at the moment, saying vaguely comforting things.

A. M. @Fletcher Christian: apparently not?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

As per this, from JPMorgan.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Blackbagg99 Well you damn well should, shame on you!
BE11:44am

We met with DBK CEO Christian Sewing and CFO James von Moltke in a group meeting and came out
reassured on management’s commitment to deliver on things which are under its control i.e. costs, balance sheet and liquidity. While we acknowledge the steps management is taking to improve 2019E RoTE towards its target of 4%+, we believe it would need help from markets and a CIB turnaround to reach this target and remain
Neutral. Our RoTE estimate of 2.6% (0.3x P/TBV) in 2019E assumes broadly flat YoY revenues (ex balance
sheet/ liquidity optimization) in 2019E vs. implied revenue growth rate of c4.5% to reach DBK target of 4%+ RoTE.

Blackbag99 @1st Why?
BE11:45am

CEO Sewing highlighted 2 phases for DBK, i.) 2018 which was about stabilization and where they
ticked on targets related to e.g. costs, capital and ii.) 2019 which is about controlled growth. While he
acknowledged that a constructive market environment and market share stabilization in CIB contributes c1%
(net of higher cost of risk and litigation costs) to bridge the gap from 0.5% to 4% ROTE, the balance 2.5%
bridge is from things which are more in their hands (costs, tax rate, b/s and liquidity optimization, growth in
stable businesses).

wayneJ One think that had not been considered is if Brexit gives a stimulus in terms of activity and tax rate equivalent to say 0.5% of GDP (and say 1 - 3% of tax take depending on the country eg Ireland ) to some north European countries?
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Management expressed confidence in reaching its 2019 cost target of €21.8bn, with half of the €1bn
planned cost savings already in the bag (from completed headcount reductions, announced sale of
businesses) and confidence around delivering on the other half. In addition, in a scenario where revenues
fall short of its expectations, management would take additional steps which may include acceleration of cost
initiatives, adjustment on compensation expense and investment spending. We are already below the cost
target in 2019E with adjusted costs of €21.6bn as we have lower revenue growth assumptions.
 4Q revenues did not fully reflect the momentum in some of the businesses which DBK plans to grow
including PCB and GTB. In addition, the raids last year did not help revenues in 4Q either. CEO Sewing
acknowledged that getting to a 4% RoTE is important to demonstrate that DBK can improve its profitability,
something which the market is skeptical on right now.

luzh "I can't stand bad grammar either." You shouldn't use "too" after a modal verb.
red pharma its this thursday

Sewing didn't comment on the merger speculation beyond saying that Deutsche has a plan in which he's confident.

Pharma @luzh, irony alert
wayneJ With DBK worth remembering it is trading at 28% of (apparently) tangible book. One of its big fallacies has been to redeploy capital in the US. If it redeployed that in Europe could actually make a big impact pan Europe

(@luzh: cant tell if your trolling us.)

FATDAZ @excel yes there is certainly something to that money transmission and distribution systems in US and Europe are widely different ie market led and bank led and that goes some way to explain why QE worked in US and doesn't seem to have done in Europe - yes US banks find it easier to raise capital and put it too work efficiently that doesn't mean they don't loose it from time to time but thats the business they are in
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Blackbag99 - Because our high-street should be a centre for our community and should provide essential services it shouldn't be sold off to a charlatan to make millions and treat employees like sh*t.

IMP.GLD Tiger Global graduates

K-NUCK Takeway are doing a deal in Germany
wayneJ @Bluesky - I agree totally with both your points. But with the leverage ratio one has to be aware how it is calculated. IIRC (am about 4 yrs out of date) I once dug into gross exposure definitions of DB vs US banks such as JPM. The US banks net off derivatives exposures whilst Europeans report them unnetted which leads to significant differences and obviously impacts your conclusions if you are not aware of this.
11:55 am

In terms of activism, it seems to be "buy a lot of one small company then buy a small amount of a big company and chew at the big company to buy the small company."

And if you want to pay 2 and 20 for that, go right ahead I guess.

I used to work for Bank of Scotland, but am looking for an opportunity to get out of LLOY as I'm so impressed by Transferwise. Just one of many disruptors who will do to the big retail banks what internet has done to the high street

11:56 am
BE11:56am

[I]t is clear that Cat Rock, without naming names, is hinting at Takeaway to be the ‘well-run industry peer’ to
merge with Just Eat. Cat Rock clearly holds Takeaway CEO Jitse Groenin high regard and they happen to own c.2.5m shares worth €143m in the company, while their c.13m shares in Just Eat are worth £91m (€104m).
Cat Rock also pitched Takeaway as a long at last year’s Sohn Conference. We could not find a disclosed stake of Cat Rock in Delivery Hero.

BE11:57am

Jitse Groen, in a recent newspaper interview said that he expects further consolidation in Europe and elsewhere. We believe that Takeaway would be interested at some point in acquiring the European assets of Just Eat (UK, France, Denmark, Ireland, Spain, Italy) but we don’t expect a deal near term considering i) Takeway’s recent acquisition of Delivery Hero’s German assets, ii) the difference in market cap (€2.9bn for Takeaway vs. £4.8bn) and iii) Brexit looming.
